F80EE9D2AE7642DAB2BE9D7FE4C9E5B2.description: Explain the Compromise of 1877 and its role in ending Radical Reconstruction.

20A9A56C0B004721881F266DE2CCB3A3.description: Explain the roles carpetbaggers and scalawags played during Reconstruction.

AF36B35DA8C2451C8960BE3C6205C4AF.description:
Trace the rise of the Ku Klux Klan and vigilante justice in the South and in Tennessee,
including the role of Governor William Brownlow.

E7BE96C9DA91467BA87727C701255859.description:
Explain the restrictions placed on the rights and opportunities of freedmen, including: racial
segregation, black codes, and the efforts of the Freedmen's Bureau to address the problems
confronting newly freed slaves.

66110D41AAED470A940DAF7C5971C232.description:
Analyze the conflict between President Andrew Johnson and the Radical Republicans,
including Johnson’s veto of the Tenure of Office Act and his impeachment.

60A20741F9D8401FBB4B196B0DDAD3BB.description:
Identify the significance of the Tennessee Constitution of 1870, including the right of all men
to vote and the establishment of a poll tax.

FA703CEEBD2648D28D46D76C6E1EF942.description:
Analyze President Abraham Lincoln’s Ten Percent Plan, President Andrew Johnson’s Plan,
and the Radical Republican Plan for Reconstruction.

E0DCD0E7BB90410D9ADC037633520AC6.description: Explain the significance of the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments to the U.S. Constitution.

53E164EC3FC24920BD523F236FF2B31D.description:
Analyze the immediate political impact of the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln
and Andrew Johnson’s ascension to the presidency.

698548F7C6EA4E19BFCF7291C0FB942A.description:
Reconstruction (1865-1877)
Overview: Students will analyze the social, economic, and political changes and conflicts during Reconstruction, the
events and lasting consequences of Reconstruction, and Reconstruction’s impact on Tennessee.

F76964BA83BE4B42AE3B5A5D47239939.description:
Analyze how the writings of Sam Watkins and Elisha Hunt Rhodes illustrated the daily life of
the common soldier.

E2814795801646CB8FDF04D31B2D63E7.description:
Describe African American involvement in the Union army, including the Massachusetts 54th
Regiment at Fort Wagner and the 13th U.S. Colored Troops in the Battle of Nashville.

D70FDC64DB844947B9BE1B63AF68CE7C.description: Analyze the significance of the Emancipation Proclamation and the Gettysburg Address.

7D643AAC049A431C8F9F961052A26A69.description:
Explain the significance of the following battles, events, and leaders during the Civil War,
including:
• First Battle of Bull Run • Surrender at Appomattox Court House
• Battle of Shiloh • David Farragut
• Battle of Antietam • Nathan Bedford Forrest
• Battle of Gettysburg • Ulysses S. Grant
• Battle of Vicksburg • Thomas “Stonewall” Jackson
• Sherman’s March to the Sea • Robert E. Lee

455165AB19864C60B8640AB18DA4F13B.description:
Describe the outbreak of the Civil War and the resulting sectional differences, including:
• Economic, geographic, and technological advances
• Military strategies
• Roles of President Abraham Lincoln and Jefferson Davis
• Significance of Fort Sumter
• Geographical divisions within states

B2C027BAC18C4AD9A7038D4D11337E21.description:
Describe the election of 1860 and its candidates (i.e., John Bell, Stephen Douglas, Abraham
Lincoln, and John Breckinridge), and analyze how the campaigns reflected sectional turmoil
in the country.

4BEFAE4A20604964BC36A425609117BF.description:
The Civil War (1860-1865)
Overview: Students will examine the political changes that sparked the Civil War, the differences in the North and South,
and the key leaders, events, battles, and daily life during the war.

535AF1A3F8E646EF88ABC336DBB705A3.description:
Explain the arguments presented by Stephen Douglas and Abraham Lincoln on slavery in the
Illinois Senate race debates of 1858.

AE261B041BFB4689929FC42C06606ACB.description:
Analyze the Dred Scott v. Sandford decision and the resulting split between the North and
South.

1DB6F0DC464B4D6EB1A4F197A709CE65.description:
Explain the motivations behind the passage of the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854, and
analyze the effects of act, including:
• Rise of the Republican Party
• “Bleeding Kansas”
• Preston Brooks’ attack on Charles Sumner
• John Brown’s raid at Harper’s Ferry

C4A66E30498D4C5CAE53394E8538DD39.description: Describe the significance of the Gadsden Purchase of 1853.

B8835F9921F142B18AAEC80DEFB7CD15.description:
Explain the reasons for and the impact of the Compromise of 1850 (including Henry Clay’s
role as “The Great Compromiser”) and the Fugitive Slave Act (including Harriet Beecher
Stowe’s influence with Uncle Tom’s Cabin).

4F94629EBCBE4619A7A255995AFF3A25.description:
Analyze the discovery of gold in California, its social and economic impact on the U.S., and
the major migratory movement (including the forty-niners and Asian immigrants).

8CEBA759EFEF4422B0EEE51F1781DAEB.description:
Describe the causes and consequences of the Mexican War, including the controversy over
the Rio Grande boundary and the Mexican Cession.

DF82AD18F0084F4991D832DC7387BE79.description:
Identify the major events and impact of James K. Polk’s presidency, including the annexation
of Texas and the settlement of the Oregon boundary.

33ED7FF405EC48D8B74FD9E5F4F9BC3A.description:
Analyze the reasons for and outcomes of groups moving west, including the significance of:
• Fur traders
• Mormons
• Oregon Trail
• Santa Fe Trail

645DACA7DA3542DDAB520834F56B4CD5.description:
Describe American settlements in Texas after 1821, the causes of the Texas War for
Independence, the roles of David Crockett and Sam Houston, and the legacy of the Alamo.

E09581AA19ED4FDFA6EEE64BBD98C3C1.description:
Explain the reasons for and the provisions of the Missouri Compromise (i.e., Compromise of
1820) and its impact on expansion.

469693DA262A4C159ABE82C743A55E92.description:
Analyze the concept of Manifest Destiny and its impact on the development of the nation,
and describe the economic incentives for westward expansion.

3D093A1DAA1147E0A0F72CDCDD3637BF.description:
Expansion and Division of the Nation (1820s-1860s)
Overview: Students will analyze the social, political, and economic impact of expansion on the U.S., the growing tensions
between the North and South, and how compromise sought to hold the country together.

4AB63858619B405FA303F9BFEAF11B60.description:
Identify that the Tennessee Constitution of 1834 expanded voting rights for non-property
owners.

9FBCA290131846D6A5FBD805AFA4D86E.description:
Describe the impact of the Indian Removal Act and the struggle between the Cherokee
Nation and the U.S. government, including the significance of Worcester v. Georgia and the
Trail of Tears.

AFD4A07C6D0D4A21A061440B57E1C090.description:
Examine President Andrew Jackson’s actions regarding the Bank of the U.S. and the
Nullification Crisis, and analyze the effects of these events on the nation.

4519077C032D417A87398F63A3953DAA.description:
Examine President Andrew Jackson’s actions regarding the Bank of the U.S. and the
Nullification Crisis, and analyze the effects of these events on the nation.

38A8DBA86C5C4337AD57D5DC2D72C7C4.description:
Analyze the role played by Chief Justice John Marshall in strengthening the judicial branch,
including the key decisions of the Supreme Court in Gibbons v. Ogden and McCulloch v.
Maryland.

2C16A298AE154B9C9505D3B8D3F5F8C2.description:
The Jacksonian Era (1824-1840)
Overview: Students will analyze the impact of John Marshall on the strengthening of the judicial branch and the major
events of Andrew Jackson’s presidency.

4763454DFB58492A8F0377C26B9F9361.description:
Analyze the significance of leading abolitionists, including William Lloyd Garrison, Frederick
Douglass, Elihu Embree, and Harriet Tubman, and the methods they used to spread the
movement.

F748097DEDF9439D942DF4E513F03716.description:
Analyze the development of the women’s suffrage movement, including the Seneca Falls
Convention, and the ideals of Susan B. Anthony, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, and Sojourner
Truth.

DDE70F17F69946FD920BE89C4E1680BB.description:
Describe the significance of the Second Great Awakening and its influence on reform in the
19th century.

5B3A3F75B49E41F388F938C9D2436CAC.description:
Analyze the development of roads, canals, railroads, and steamboats throughout the U.S.,
including the Erie Canal and the National Road.

1434B9CFEF3F4BD79FB9A2CC5A723522.description:
Identify the push-pull factors for Irish and German immigrants, and describe the impact of
their arrival in the U.S. prior to the Civil War.

1514C6FDD0A641B6BAC04ABC47940777.description:
Identify the push-pull factors for Irish and German immigrants, and describe the impact of
their arrival in the U.S. prior to the Civil War.

DD50C7FBF9EB42C9930A6235DC8E4906.description:
Explain the development of the American Industrial Revolution, including:
• Eli Whitney and interchangeable
parts • Role of the textile industry
• Emergence of trade unions • Samuel Slater
• Lowell System

BD7814D85C11424FAD9C31092F4888B8.description:
Identify the conditions of enslavement, and explain how slaves adapted to and resisted
bondage in their daily lives, including Nat Turner's revolt.

3E01B0019C91405EB86C69B4B852C544.description:
Analyze the characteristics of Southern society and its influence on the social and political
conditions prior to the Civil War.

53FD95ADD2914DD2BD0DBDCDD87872FF.description:
Describe the development of the agrarian economy in the South, the locations of the cottonproducing states, the significance of cotton and the cotton gin, and the founding of Memphis
as a center for cotton and the slave trade.

6C3186C3FE294BC8A1FB9BFF296D46C2.description:
Sectionalism and Reform (1790s-1850s)
Overview: Students will analyze the social, political, and economic development of the North and South during the early
19th century, including the growth of sectionalism and reform movements.

C2B36824F7D44C22A1BFB890A887B7CB.description: Analyze the purpose and effects of the Monroe Doctrine.

13BFAFFC5B8841BAB0516F32983467EE.description:
Identify and locate the changing boundaries of the U.S. as a result of the Convention of 1818
and the Adams-Onis Treaty.

1D29BD4FAA9440509661881D72ABA877.description:
Explain the causes, course, and consequences of the War of 1812, including:
• Use of impressment and trade restrictions between the U.S. and Great Britain
• Roles of Andrew Jackson and William Henry Harrison
• Significance of the Treaty of Ghent
• Rise in nationalism in the U.S.

CFCDC19DA312458884AB0909CCB8ED15.description:
Explain the major events of Thomas Jefferson’s presidency, including:
• Conflict with the Barbary pirates
• Embargo Act
• Lewis and Clark Expedition
• Louisiana Purchase

DBCCC656DA7B4D61A13E6593F4B8AC00.description:
Analyze the significance of the election of 1800 and Chief Justice John Marshall’s opinion in
Marbury v. Madison.

248B09C84BF5465B9F5A5F20D8834DFA.description:
The New Nation (1775-1800)
Overview: Students will explore the foundation of U.S. government, the principles of the Articles of Confederation and the
U.S. Constitution, and the individuals who played influential roles in the development of the new nation. In addition,
students will examine the steps taken by Tennessee to achieve statehood and the initial development of government.

BE7A38D58C9149A89ADD0DF3FDF6AE28.description:
Identify how westward expansion led to the statehood of Tennessee and the importance of
the first state constitution (1796).

3D14116434B243278E7369625187BB3A.description:
Explain the controversies that plagued the administration of President John Adams,
including: the conflicts with Great Britain and France, the XYZ Affair, and the Alien and
Sedition Acts.

A4A8746574C44ACC828F0D8E6EBB4090.description:
Explain how conflicts between Thomas Jefferson and Alexander Hamilton resulted in the
emergence of two political parties by analyzing their views on foreign policy, economic policy,
a national bank, and strict versus loose interpretation of the Constitution.

B318929634E44DD092B71AC44A186030.description:
Analyze the major events of the administration of President George Washington, including:
the precedents he set, Whiskey Rebellion, and ideas presented in his farewell address.

0BB47771E3B141AA8C71894DFD44BEBA.description:
Describe the conflict between Federalists and Anti-Federalists over the ratification of the
Constitution, including the protection of individual rights through the Bill of Rights and
concern for states’ rights.

7E8D07552C04491C90C8E20408CA1AD5.description:
Examine the principles and purposes of government articulated in the Preamble and
principles stated in the Constitution, including: the separation of powers, federalism, and
checks and balances.

BFAA971BE5924128BF26BC88197331EB.description:
Describe the roles of James Madison and George Washington during the Constitutional
Convention, and analyze the major issues debated, including the Great Compromise and the
Three-Fifths Compromise.

D1DDEC35DDAF498595F82DB4542999A6.description:
Analyze the strengths and weaknesses of the Articles of Confederation, and describe the
Land Ordinance of 1785, the Northwest Ordinance of 1787, the Northwest Territory, the Lost
State of Franklin, and Shays’ Rebellion.

7612812F6B1E45E99638A9E41EB5B05F.description:
The New Nation (1775-1800)
Overview: Students will explore the foundation of U.S. government, the principles of the Articles of Confederation and the
U.S. Constitution, and the individuals who played influential roles in the development of the new nation. In addition,
students will examine the steps taken by Tennessee to achieve statehood and the initial development of government.

9256B30BC7AA4245B4A6030CA3762079.description:
Locate and explain the significance of the following during the American Revolution:
• Struggles of the Continental Army • Battle of Saratoga
• Battles of Trenton and Princeton • Battle of Yorktown
• Battle of Kings Mountain • Guerrilla warfare

E84AE81E320A439C98C52624A5974FD4.description: Compare and contrast the points of view of Loyalists and Patriots.

892141A153924838B2628872874015D2.description: Explain the historical and present-day significance of the Declaration of Independence.

128779B970CF47F584D5D2D251C6DA2E.description:
Locate and explain the significance of the battles of the American Revolution prior to the
signing of the Declaration of Independence, including Lexington and Concord and Bunker
(Breed’s) Hill.

5401FE9112244D628B923C18160717AD.description: Explain the historical purposes and consequences of Thomas Paine's Common Sense.

A8186BE32D524A6385B6D5FFC26EF7AC.description:
Analyze the social, political, and economic causes of the events and groups of the American
Revolution, including:
• The Quartering Act, 1765 • The Boston Massacre, 1770
• The Stamp Act, 1765 • The Boston Tea Party, 1773
• The Declaratory Act, 1766 • Intolerable/Coercive Acts, 1774
• The Townshend Acts, 1767 • Sons of Liberty

21F3F2481CD64636945543D712A6A8EB.description:
Explain the political contributions of Benjamin Franklin to the U.S., including the "Join or Die"
cartoon and Albany Plan of Union.

F79FD60DF93E44FEAE67A66F65200E81.description:
Explain the significance of the Ohio River Valley leading to the French and Indian War and
the events and consequences of the conflict, including: the massacre at Fort Loudoun, the
Treaty of Paris of 1763, war debt, and the Proclamation Line of 1763.

AA797D0B318E4A34BEB6C5317338D23A.description:
The American Revolution (1700-1783)
Overview: Students will explore the growing tensions between Great Britain and its colonies as well as the major events
and outcomes surrounding the American Revolution.

84EF206BFEE2463C925208079EDB83C1.description: Explain the Navigation Acts and the policy of mercantilism.

4BEFB5F3EE7B46DB9DEF3AA8DD935FB7.description:
Describe the significance of the First Great Awakening, including its role in unifying the
colonies and the growth of religious tolerance.

A76B4388CEF9485B81F8EFAE1443B5EA.description:
Identify the origins and development of slavery in the colonies, overt and passive resistance
to enslavement, and the Middle Passage.

350D06C4357C44B790DDC982F4D9341F.description:
Compare and contrast the locations and goals of British, French, and Spanish settlements in
North America.

FF955937C5524F72BD777F7281C596AF.description:
Locate and identify the Thirteen Colonies, and describe how their location and geographic
features influenced regional economic development.

246C819A753442758F6441DABFE7931B.description:
Explain the reasons behind the settlement of the Georgia Colony, including: its designation
as a “debtor” colony, its function as a “buffer” colony, and the role of James Oglethorpe in its
founding.

756EE6AA6D794C118649F5B8CF34AFD7.description:
Analyze the founding of Pennsylvania as a haven for Quakers and the tolerance that drew
many different groups to the colony, including the significance of:
• William Penn
• Philadelphia
• Relationship with American Indians
• Role of women

169A48FA450F4B92BA34BDDAFE3A6745.description:
Analyze the economic motivation for the Dutch founding New Netherlands, the diverse
population of the colony, and the transition to the English colony of New York.

B3740EC87BFF4D5291AA575FDC696B3C.description:
Explain the motivation for and the founding of the Rhode Island and Connecticut Colonies,
including the roles of Roger Williams and Thomas Hooker.

9AD123899CC541A999C6D9BC4B5794C0.description:
Explain the founding and development of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, including the
significance of:
• Anne Hutchinson
• Role of theocracy
• Salem Witch Trials
• Town meetings

03ED2F20573F414689846C27E562C34B.description:
Explain the founding and development of the Plymouth Colony, including the significance of:
the Mayflower Compact, interactions with Squanto, and the role of religious freedom.

581A5BBD5C4C4F019C56A87CF3670FFB.description:
Explain the founding and development of Jamestown as the first permanent English colony,
its early struggles, the economic and political structure, and role of the Powhatan people.

C2A16A31A58A480E9B1ED13BD59A53EB.description:
Colonization (1607-1750)
Overview: Students will examine the European settlement of North America, geographic features that influenced early
colonies, and the social, religious, political, and economic reasons for colonization.
